text: Hi everyone, I wanted to ask if Julia could be used for Blockchain development ?

elements.text: Hi everyone, I wanted to ask if Julia could be used for Blockchain development ?

text: Sure, why not? Julia's good for it if you need high speed of development and high execution speed. It's not so good ad making guarantees about how the code behaves. So if you plan on making the next big bitcoin wallet, you might want to go with C++ or Rust

elements.text: Sure, why not? Julia's good for it if you need high speed of development and high execution speed. It's not so good ad making guarantees about how the code behaves. So if you plan on making the next big bitcoin wallet, you might want to go with C++ or Rust

text: Okay, thank you for your reply

elements.text: Okay, thank you for your reply

text: though blockchain development is more than just designing wallets or chains. there will likely be valuable uses for Julia implementations for the API of various chains and projects. For example, an interface for running Julia programs on SingularityNet.

text: Can someone please explain to me whether blockchain is actually a thing or not? All the really smart people I talk to say it's a scam. But there's so much stuff on the internet about how important it is for the future of humanity or something

elements.text: Can someone please explain to me whether blockchain is actually a thing or not? All the really smart people I talk to say it's a scam. But there's so much stuff on the internet about how important it is for the future of humanity or something

text: <https://thecorrespondent.com/655/blockchain-the-amazing-solution-for-almost-nothing/86649455475-f933fe63>

attachments.title: Blockchain, the amazing solution for almost nothing
attachments.text: Blockchain technology is going to change everything: the shipping industry, the financial system, government … in fact, what won’t it change? But enthusiasm for it mainly stems from a lack of knowledge and understanding. The blockchain is a solution in search of a problem.
attachments.fallback: The Correspondent: Blockchain, the amazing solution for almost nothing

text: That's an entertaining- and depressing - read. "So much energy that the two biggest blockchains in the world – bitcoin and Ethereum – are now using up the same amount of electricity as the whole of Austria.  Carrying out a payment with Visa requires about 0.002 kilowatt-hours; the same payment with bitcoin uses up 906 kilowatt-hours, more than half a million times as much, and enough to power a two-person household for about three months."

elements.text: That's an entertaining- and depressing - read. "So much energy that the two biggest blockchains in the world – bitcoin and Ethereum – are now using up the same amount of electricity as the whole of Austria.  Carrying out a payment with Visa requires about 0.002 kilowatt-hours; the same payment with bitcoin uses up 906 kilowatt-hours, more than half a million times as much, and enough to power a two-person household for about three months."

text: that's horrendous...

elements.text: that's horrendous...

text: And that power is being consumed by ASICs that are improving so quickly that a almost 100g of electronic waste is created per transaction

elements.text: And that power is being consumed by ASICs that are improving so quickly that a almost 100g of electronic waste is created per transaction

text:
“blockchain” as a handwavy way to refer to this entire domain of decentralized/cryptographic technology, not the specific data-structure or project like bitcoin, in my opinion, isn’t any more or less a scam than machine learning. whether you think ML is also a complete scam or an exciting research domain is a similar question.

As an ML researcher, and definitely not a crypto researcher, I can’t comment directly on scaminess. But a lot of really smart people base their opinions entirely on of opinions by other people, who themselves based it on opinions by other… Derivative opinions aren’t really useful signals. Lots of the discussion I see about this feels more like in-group demonstrations against the culture surrounding decentralized finance.

It’s not surprising to me that people are put off by the finance and speculative hype that’s built up around the technology. But I also see a lot of hype and speculation around ML research that is largely incidental to the merits of the research. Obviously I believe there’s valuable work, solutions to real things, to be done in ML research. Whether that value is visible to outsiders who have to look past the ML hype and certain aspects of our culture is unclear.

I am more than comfortable extending that to blockchain research area. There are real research problems and solutions and technology. There are also shitty cultural aspects, speculators, profiteers, and predators.

it is easy to look at, e.g.,  the energy cost of bitcoin as an easy opportunity to dismiss an entire field as myopic, irresponsible, and dangerous. how much energy do large ML models cost to train? massive hyperparameter sweeps of massive models where most of the work is thrown away? yes, it’s a real problem. It seems to me that people involved in the work are working on it. people interested in making hot takes and collecting hacker news clout will continue to behave accordingly. I don’t think unfounded naysaying is  any more correct than reckless overhyped speculation.

text: That's hardly analogous. ML is an actually useful technology implemented in actual products. Blockchain isn't, that's the whole point. Using massive amounts of power isn't necessarily bad - so does aluminum refineries, but they're actually useful

elements.text: That's hardly analogous. ML is an actually useful technology implemented in actual products. Blockchain isn't, that's the whole point. Using massive amounts of power isn't necessarily bad - so does aluminum refineries, but they're actually useful

attachments.title: Do you need a blockchain?
attachments.text: A decision helper for the most intriguing new technology ever!

text: The math checks out, it's just not very useful for/there are alternatives better suited to the kinds of tasks people want to use it for

elements.text: The math checks out, it's just not very useful for/there are alternatives better suited to the kinds of tasks people want to use it for

text:
whether blockchain, ML, or aluminum refinery is “actually useful” is what is at issue. simply saying one is and one isn’t is not helpful.

ML has *direct analogy* to many of the qualities that blockchain is criticized for. In many many many instances where it is “actually useful”, like blockchain, it is likely a massive overkill for the problem.  there is an opportunity for an equally cynical website <http://doyouneedaneuralnetwork.com/>
I also happen to be an ML researcher, so I am using my experience of cynical perceptions of my field to inform my check against my cynical impressions of others’ work.

using a massive amount of power isn’t necessarily bad. I agree. I am referring directly to the article that was posted above about energy usage.  likewise, having a bunch of speculative hype around a field isn’t necessarily bad. I am saying that these signals are often used by people to make unfounded blanket statements like “blockchain isn’t useful”.

I think the least useful members of any technical effort are the cynics.

text: You don't think it's useful to look at a massive tidewave of hype and call out the bullshit? I do. Going along with groupthink - when it's unsubstantiated by any reasoning - is harmful.

elements.text: You don't think it's useful to look at a massive tidewave of hype and call out the bullshit? I do. Going along with groupthink - when it's unsubstantiated by any reasoning - is harmful.

text:
It may have been a little subtle, but I do actually agree that blockchains have some use - in the limited usecase of trying to build a distributed ledger where you can't trust any individual participant.

The same goes for ML though - if you're trying to approximate some unknown function and have a lot of proven heuristics to limit your search space, you can definitely use ML to enhance your pipeline. Using only ML to do a certain task is (in the vast majority of cases) more wasteful than a mixed approach (cf. combining the two best algorithms for a task to create one "super" algorithm that's better than either)

text:
Cynicism, not criticism, doesn’t engage with the work in good faith. Makes no effort to contribute solutions. Unfortunately, it’s a lot more accessible, and cynical thinking feels a lot like critical thinking.

Take the issue about the energy cost of bitcoin. (again, I think this is a real issue). That article does not appear to be aware of the significant work by researchers in the field to address that specific problem. Does not talk about alternatives to Proof of Work consensus….

text:
because you haven’t heard of it does not mean it does not exist. just because it doesn’t exist, in a 10 year old field, doesn’t mean it won’t.

> You don’t think it’s useful to look at a massive tidewave of hype and call out the bullshit? I do. 
Again, I think that hype around a technical field is not a good reason to call bullshit on the contributions or work of the field.

> Going along with groupthink - when it’s unsubstantiated by any reasoning - is harmful.
Agreed, especially cynical groupthink whose definition of in-group behaviour is unsubstantiated dismissal.

text:
if only there were some group of people who cared deeply and technically about how groups with different beliefs, goals, practices, and definitions of value could relate to each other and build consensus.

too bad the research area that ostensibly cares about this is populated entirely by researchers who are unambiguously more harmful and inconsiderate than the research pursuits I am familiar with and value.
